{{more citations needed|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox order |title=Order of the Golden Ark |image=Medal, order (AM 2014.7.62-15).jpg |caption=Kingdom of the Netherlands Commander of the Order of the Golden Ark badge of order |image2=[[File:Order of the Golden Ark.png|85px]] |caption2=Ribbon of the order |type=Order of Merit |for=Significant contributions to nature conservation |date=1971 |country=the {{NLD}} |house= |religion= |ribbon= |head_title=Grand Master |head= [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands|King Willem-Alexander]] |head2_title= |head2= |grades=Commander
Officer
Knight |notes= |higher=[[Bailiwick of Utrecht|Teutonic Order, Bailiwick of Utrecht]] |lower= [[Cross for the Four Day Marches]]
Awards of Dutch [[NGO]]'s }} The Most Excellent '''Order of the Golden Ark''' ({{lang-nl|Orde van de Gouden Ark}}) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[order of merit]] established in 1971 by [[Prince Bernhard of Lippe-Biesterfeld|Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands]]. It is awarded to people for major contributions to [[nature conservation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/microsites/princephilip/MicroObject.asp?item=6&themeid=1934&object=8890472&row=6&detail=about |title=Prince Philip: Celebrating Ninety Years |publisher=Royal Collection |date= |accessdate=15 October 2012}} Although not awarded by the government of the [[Netherlands]], it is considered by the government as a recognized chivalrous order.{{cite web|title=The Dutch Honours System|url=http://lintjes.nl/files/brochure%20het%20nederlandse%20decoratiestel%20in%20vijf%20talen.pdf|work=lintjes.nl/|publisher=Chancellor of the Dutch Orders|accessdate=15 October 2012}} Since its inception, over 300 people have been recognised by the award. Now that Prince Bernhard has died, the future of the order is uncertain. ==Notable recipients== * [[Ranjit Bhargava]]{{cite web |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/ranjit-bhargava-awarded-the-order-of-the-golden-ark-by-prince-bernhard-of-the-netherlands/1/265757.html |title=India Today |publisher=India Today |date=December 14, 1998 |accessdate=November 14, 2014}} * [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl Gustav of Sweden]] * [[Gerald Durrell]]{{cite web |url=http://www.durrell.org/about/gerald-durrell/gerald-durrell/ |title=Gerald Durrell O.B.E. |publisher=Durrell Wildlife Conservation Trust |accessdate=2015-05-03}} * [[Sylvia Earle]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/explorers/bios/sylvia-earle/|title=Sylvia Earle, Oceanographer Information, Facts, News, Photos -- National Geographic|last=Society|first=National Geographic|access-date=2016-07-25}} * [[Tony Fitzjohn]]{{cite web|url=http://www.georgeadamson.org/bornwild |title=GAWPT: Born Wild |publisher=Georgeadamson.org |date= |accessdate=15 October 2012}} * [[Zafar Futehally]]http://www.kolkatabirds.com/zafarinterview.htm#sthash.r6yzcHwe.FVBEbB7v.dpbs * [[Jane Goodall]]{{cite web|url=http://www.janegoodall.ca/goodall-awards.php |title=Awards & Distinctions |publisher=Jane Goodall Institute of Canada |date= |accessdate=15 October 2012}} * [[Gyanendra of Nepal]]{{cite web|url=http://www.royalark.net/Nepal/nepal13.htm|title=Nepal13|website=www.royalark.net}} * [[Roger Tory Peterson]]{{cite book|title=Who was who in America : with world notables : Volume XII, 1996-1998.|year=1998|publisher=Marquis Who's Who|location=New Providence, NJ|isbn=9780837902296|page=193}} * [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]] * [[Ian Player]] * [[Suman Sahai]]{{cite news revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.4)
revision.text:
<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|Index of religion-related articles}} The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to religion:
'''[[Religion]]''' – organized collection of beliefs, cultural systems, and world views that relate humanity to an order of existence. Many religions have narratives, symbols, and sacred histories that are intended to explain the meaning of life and/or to explain the origin of life or the Universe. From their beliefs about the cosmos and human nature, people derive morality, ethics, religious laws or a preferred lifestyle. According to some estimates, there are roughly 4,200 religions in the world.
[[File:RELIGIONES.png|thumb|Religious symbols in clock-wise order: [[Judaism]], [[Christianity]], [[Islam]], [[Bahá'í Faith]], [[Hinduism]], [[Taoism]], [[Buddhism]], [[Sikhism]], [[Slavic neopaganism]], [[Celtic polytheism]], [[Germanic neopaganism|Heathenism (German paganism)]], [[Semitic neopaganism]], [[Wicca]], [[Kemetism|Kemetism (Egyptian paganism)]], [[Hellenism (religion)|Hellenism]], [[Italo-Roman neopaganism]].]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Porcellian Club | nrhp_type = | image = 1324 Massachusetts Ave Cambridge MA.jpg | image_size = 125 | caption = | coordinates = {{coord|42|22|22.55|N|71|07|04.10|W|display=inline,title}} | location = 1320-24 Massachusetts Ave
[[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], Massachusetts | nearest_city = | area = | built = | architect = | architecture = | designated = | added = June 30, 1983 | established = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | refnum =83000824 | mpsub = Cambridge MRA | governing_body = | nrhp_type2 = cp | nocat = yes | designated_nrhp_type2 = July 28, 1988 | partof = [[Harvard Square Historic District]] | partof_refnum = 86003654 }} The '''Porcellian Club''' is an all-male [[Officially unrecognized Harvard College social clubs|final club]] at [[Harvard University]], sometimes called '''the Porc''' or '''the P.C.''' The year of founding is usually given as 1791, when a group began meeting under the name "the Argonauts,"{{cite book |year =1901 | title = Student Life and Customs | first = Henry Davidson | last = Sheldon | publisher = D. Appleton}}, p. 171: source for 1791 origins as the "Argonauts" later named "The Pig Club", "The Gentlemen's Club" and finally "The Porcellian". "Small as the membership has been, the roll of graduates shows many of the most famous of the Sons of Harvard, including Wendell Phillips, Channing, [Joseph] Story, [Edward] Everett, Prescott, Adams, Palfrey, Charles Sumner, Oliver Wendell Holmes, James Russell Lowell and John Lothrop Motley." Online at [https://books.google.com/books?vid=LCCN01026592&id=lkIb9aPJje0C&pg=RA1-PA171 Google Books] or as 1794, the year of the roast pig dinner at which the club, known first as "the Pig Club"{{cite book | first = Douglas | last = Shand-Tucci | title = Harvard University |year =2001|publisher = Princeton Architectural Press|isbn=1-56898-280-1}} p. 89: "...Harvard's still-extant Porcellian Club, which arose out of a legendary dinner of roast pig (hence the club's name) in 1794 at Moore's Tavern. Unlike [Phi Beta Kappa], the Porcellian's motto, ''Dum Vivimus Vivamus,'' indicates that they were not beguiled by concerns academical or even literary, but, rather by pure conviviality. was formally founded. The club's motto, ''[[Dum vivimus vivamus]]'' (while we live, let us live) is [[Epicurean]]. The club emblem is the pig and some members sport golden pigs on watch-chains or neckties bearing pig's-head emblems.Sedgwick, John, "Brotherhood of the Pig", GQ: Gentlemen's Quarterly 58 (November 1988), p. 30, as quoted by {{cite book | first = Richard P. | last = Horwitz | title = Hog Ties : Pigs, Manure and Mortality in American Culture |year = 1998 | publisher = Palgrave MacMillan|isbn = 0-312-21443-X}} pp. 27-28: ""My father was generally oblivious to the animal world, but he did have an unusual affection for pigs. Around our house... he had porcelain pigs, ceramic pigs, carved pigs, embroidered pigs, painted pigs.... They overran our living-room mantelpiece, swept over the tabletops, covered his bureau, popped up on his cuff links, watch chain and ties and even appeared on our drinking glasses and saltcellar.... Why all these pigs? Because my father was a Brother Porcellian... the pig is the club's emblem."{{cite book | title = The Coming of the New Deal | first =Arthur Meier | last = Schlesinger | year = 2003 | publisher = Houghton Mifflin | isbn = 0-618-34086-6| origyear = 1958}} p. 461. [NYSE president] [[Richard Whitney (financier)|Richard Whitney]] "had attended Groton and Harvard.... his clubs were the Links, the Turf, the Field, the Racquet and the Knickerbocker; from his watch chain there dangled the gold pig of Harvard's Porcellian." The club was originally started by a group of 30 students from Massachusetts who wanted to avoid the dining halls and their food by roasting pigs. The Porcellian is the iconic "hotsy-totsy final club,"{{cite book | first = Anton | last = Myrer | title = The Last Convertible | year = 2002 | publisher = HarperCollins |isbn= 0-06-093405-0}} p. 130, "I ... pulled up in front of the Porcellian or Sphinx or Onyx or whichever hotsy-totsy final club it was" often bracketed with [[Yale]]'s [[Skull and Bones]], [[Princeton University|Princeton]]'s [[Ivy Club]], [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]]'s [[Sphinx (senior society)|Sphinx Club]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]]'s [[Pitt Club]], and [[University of Oxford|Oxford]]'s [[Bullingdon Club]]. A history of Harvard calls the Porcellian "the most final of them all."{{cite book | title = Making Harvard Modern: The Rise of America's University| first = Morton | last = Keller |author2=Phyllis Keller | publisher = Oxford University Press U.S. | isbn = 0-19-514457-0 |year = 2001}} p. 472 ==Founding== According to a ''Harvard Crimson'' article of February 23, 1887:{{quote|This society was established in 1791. It occupies rooms on Harvard street and owns a library of some 7000 volumes. Its members are taken from the senior, junior and sophomore classes about eight from each class. The origin of its name is popularly supposed to be as follows: In the year 1791, a student brought a pig into his room in Hollis. In those days the window-seats were merely long boxes with lids, used to store articles in. Said student having an antipathy to the proctor who roomed beneath, was accustomed to squeeze piggy's ears and make him squeal whenever said proctor was engaged in the study of the classics. The result would be a rush by the proctor for the student's rooms, where the student was to be found studying (?), peacefully seated on his window-seat. Piggy, in the mean time had been deposited beneath, and no sound disturbed the tranquillity of the scene. On the departure of the hated proctor, a broad grin would spread over the countenance of the joker and in a little while the scene would be repeated with variations. But when it was rumored that his room was to be searched by the faculty, the joker determined to cheat them of their prey. So he invited some of his classmates to the room and the pig being cooked, all present partook of a goodly feast. They enjoyed their midnight meal so much that they determined then and there to form a club and have such entertainments periodically. In order to render historical the origin of the club and also to give it a classic touch, they decided to call it the Porcellian from Latin "porcus." In 1831, the society bearing the name of the "Order of the Knights of the Square Table" was joined to the Porcellian, as "the objects and interests of the two societies were identical."}} An 1891 article from ''The Cambridge Chronicle'' recounts the early members of the club: {{quote|Among those who presided at the initial dinners of the club were Robert Treat Paine and Henderson Inches, class of 1792; Charles Cutter, class of 1793; and Rev. Joseph McKean, L.L.D. of 1794. It is to Mr. McKean that the club owes not only its pig, but its principles.{{cite news|url=http://cambridge.dlconsulting.com/cgi-bin/cambridge?a=d&d=Chronicle18910228-01.2.61|title= Wee, Wee, Wee - The Time-Honored Dinner of the Porcellian Club|newspaper=The Cambridge Chronicle|date=February 28, 1891|page=6}}}} ==Clubhouse== [[File:Porcellian menu NYPL Dig ID 474167.jpg|thumb|left|A menu from a dinner at the Porcellian Club 1884 (original in the Buttolph collection of menus, [[New York Public Library|NYPL]])]] The Porcellian clubhouse is located at 1324 [[Massachusetts Avenue (Cambridge)|Massachusetts Avenue]] above the store of clothier J. August. The building was designed by the architect and clubmember William York Peters.{{cite web|url=http://www.bullworks.net/virtual/signat/peters.htm |title=Peters - Sprague Corkscrew |publisher=Bullworks.net |date= |accessdate=2015-05-02}} Its entrance faces the Harvard freshman dormitories and the entrance to [[Harvard Yard]] called the Porcellian, or McKean, Gate. The gate was donated by the club in 1901 and features a limestone carving of a boar's head.{{cite news|author=Gewertz, Ken|title=Enter to grow in wisdom: A tour of Harvard's gates|newspaper=[[The Harvard Gazette]]'|date=December 15, 2005|url=http://www.news.harvard.edu/gazette/2005/12.15/18-gates.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825133807/http://www.news.harvard.edu/gazette/2005/12.15/18-gates.html|archivedate=August 25, 2007|df=}} Access to the clubhouse is strictly limited to members, but non-members are allowed in the first floor room known as the Bicycle Room. Despite the exclusivity and mystique, some, like ''[[National Review]]'' columnist/editor, [[Ronald Reagan]] speechwriter and [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] emeritus professor of English [[Jeffrey Hart]], have noted the club's modest physical and metaphorical character. Hart (who had never actually been inside the club) wrote: {{quote|...To illustrate, may I invoke Harvard's famous Porcellian, an undergraduate club of extraordinary exclusiveness? ... [I]t is devilishly hard to join. But there is nothing there, hardly a club at all. The quarters consist entirely of a large room over a row of stores in Harvard Square. There is a bar, a billiards table and a mirror arranged so that members can sit and view Massachusetts Avenue outside without themselves being seen. That's it...Porcellian is the pinnacle of the Boston idea. Less is more. Zero is a triumph.{{cite journal|author=Hart, Jeffrey|title=What is American?|journal=National Review|volume=48|date=April 22, 1996|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1282/is_n7_v48/ai_18211331|page=4}}}} [[File:DeCamp Joseph The Steward.jpg|thumb|''The Steward'' (1919) by [[Joseph DeCamp]].]] A portrait of George Washington Lewis, titled "The Steward (Lewis of the Porcellian)" by [[Joseph DeCamp]], hangs in the clubhouse. An obituary in ''TIME'' magazine on April 1, 1929 notes:
George Washington Lewis, of Cambridge, Massachusetts, for over 45 years the esteemed Negro steward of the Porcellian Club at Harvard College; in Cambridge, Massachusetts Ancient and most esoteric of Harvard clubs is Porcellian, founded in 1791.* An oil portrait of Steward Lewis hangs in the clubhouse. Steward Lewis had ten Porcellian pallbearers.
===Interior=== The interior of the then-new clubhouse was described in an 1891 article in the ''Cambridge Chronicle'':
The enlargement of the club's library, and the fact of its growing postgraduate or honorary membership roll, compelled it from time to time to enlarge its accommodations. Finally, in 1881, it determined to tear down the old house where it had so long met, on Harvard street and build a new structure its site. The new structure is of brick, handsomely trimmed in stone, and rises to the height of four stories, with about seventy or eighty feet of frontage on Harvard street. Two large stores claim a part of the ground floor, but they do not encroach on the broad and handsome entrance to the club's apartments. The three upper floors are used exclusively by the club. The first of them contains a large hall which opens both into the front and rear reception rooms and parlors, which, in turn, communicate. From each of these rooms a door leads to the library, which extends through from the front to the rear. On the second floor, in addition to a room over the library, there is a billiard hall in the front and a breakfast room in the rear with the kitchen over the main hall of the floor beneath. Nearly the whole of the top floor is taken up by a large banquet hall, vaulted by handsome rafters.
==Historical significance== [[Theodore Roosevelt]] and other members of the extended Roosevelt family belonged to the Porcellian, but the club did not invite Harvard sophomore [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] to join. FDR joined the [[Fly Club]] instead, along with his roommate, and eventually three of his sons. According to relative Sheffield Cowles, however, FDR, in his late thirties, declared, perhaps hyperbolically, that not being "punched" by the Porc was "the greatest disappointment in his life."Frances Richardson Keller, ''Fictions of U. S. History : A Theory & Four Illustrations'', Bloomington, Indiana: Indiana University Press, 2002, p. 116. Additionally, the young [[Joseph P. Kennedy]], Sr. received no invitation to join the Porc; a biographer writes that "For years later, Joe Kennedy remembered the day he didn't make the Porcellian Club, the most desired in his mind, realizing that none of the Catholics he knew at Harvard had been selected."{{cite book|title=The Kennedys: America's Emerald Kings|author=Thomas Maier|publisher=Basic Books|year=2004|isbn=0-465-04317-8}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yCmmPID9HLQC&pg=PA72&as_brr=3&ei=Ih4qSJG1GKe-ygTrz-iPCw&sig=BdkxViimyCtu-3tOKo-EuJYg5Ow#PPA72,M1 p. 72] An 1870 travel book said:
A notice of Harvard would be as incomplete without a reference to the Porcellian Club as a notice of Oxford or Cambridge would be in which the Union Debating Society held no place. This and the [[Hasty Pudding Club]], an organization for performing amateur theatricals, are the two lions of Harvard. The Porcellian Club is hardly a place of resort for those who cultivate the intellect at the expense of the body. The list of active members is small, owing in part to the largeness of the annual subscription. The great desire of every student is to become a member of it... the doings of the club are shrouded in secrecy... All that can be said by a stranger who has been privileged to step behind the scenes is that the mysteries are rites which can be practised without much labor and yield a pleasure which is fraught with no unpleasant consequences.{{cite book | first = W. Fraser | last = Rae | title = Westward by Rail: The New Route to the East|publisher = Longmans, Green, And Co. |year=1870}} p. 354-5. [https://books.google.com/books?vid=LCCNrc01001531&id=AzhNeh9Mv8cC&pg=PA354&printsec=8 Google Books text] A telling indication of the position of the Porcellian in the Boston establishment is given by a historian of Boston's [[Trinity Church, Boston|Trinity Church]], Porcellian member [[H. H. Richardson]]'s architectural masterpiece. In speculating as to why Richardson was chosen, he writes, "The thirty-four-year-old possessed one great advantage over the other candidates: as a popular Harvard undergraduate he had been a member of several clubs, including the prestigious Porcellian; thus he needed no introduction to the rector, [[Phillips Brooks]], or five of the eleven-man building committee—they were all fellow Porcellian members."{{cite book | first = James F. | last = O'Gorman | title = The Makers of Trinity Church in the City of Boston | year = 2004 | publisher = [[University of Massachusetts Press]] | isbn = 1-55849-436-7}} p. 14
== Membership criteria == A biography of [[Norman Mailer]] says that when he was at Harvard, "It would have been unthinkable... for a Jew to be invited to join one of the so-called final clubs like Porcellian, [[A.D. Club]], [[Fly Club|Fly]], or [[Spee Club (Harvard)|Spee]]."{{cite book | first = Mary | last = Dearborn | title = Mailer: A Biography | year = 2001 | publisher = Houghton Mifflin | isbn=0-618-15460-4}} p. 23 A history of Harvard notes the decline in [[Boston Brahmin]] influence at Harvard during the last quarter of the 1900s, and says "a third of [the presidents of the Final Clubs] were Jewish by 1986 and one was black. The Porcellian... took an occasional Jew and in 1983 (to the horror of some elders) admitted an African-American—who had gone to [[St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire)|St. Paul's]]." More recent information on the membership of the Porcellian Club may be found in a 1994 Harvard Crimson article by Joseph Mathews. He writes, "Prep school background, region and legacy status do not appear to be the sole determinants of membership they may once have been, but ... they remain factors."{{cite news |url= http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=239916 |title= So Many NB Candidates At Old Barn |author= Matthews, Joe |date= March 5, 1994 |newspaper= [[The Harvard Crimson]] |access-date= 2016-10-11 }} As of 2016, the club only admitted male members, and defended “the value of single gender institutions for men and women as a supplement and option to coeducational institutions”.{{cite web | last=Fahs | first=C. Ramsey | title=In Most Extensive Comments in Centuries, Porcellian Club Criticizes Final Club Scrutiny | website=The Harvard Crimson | date=2016-04-12 | url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2016/4/13/porcellian-club-criticizes-college/ | access-date=2017-10-25}} ==Joseph McKean Gate== [[File:McKean Gate (Harvard Yard) - IMG 9039.JPG|thumb|McKean Gate.]] In 1901 a gate to Harvard Yard, directly opposite the clubhouse, was erected. According to a notice published in the Harvard Crimson, on March 20, 1909:
A gate is to be erected at the entrance to the Yard between Wadsworth House and Boylston Hall. It is to be erected by members of the Porcellian Club in memory of Joseph McKean 1794, S.T.D., LL.D. Boylston Professor of Rhetoric, Oratory and Elocution, and also the founder of the Porcellian Club.
The gate prominently features the club's symbol, a boar's head, directly above the central arch and is a famous Harvard landmark. ==Notable members== {{more citations needed|date=November 2016}} *[[Joseph Alsop]] (1932) – Journalist, author of ''The 168 Days'' (1938) regarding FDR's plan to pack the Supreme Court. Great-nephew of Theodore Roosevelt. *[[William Astor Chanler]] – Soldier, explorer and U.S. Congressman from NY (1899-1901) *[[John Jay Chapman]] (1884, L.L.D. 1887) – Author, ''Emerson and Other Essays'', translator Dante, Sophocles. Brother-in-law of William Chanler *Justice [[Benjamin Robbins Curtis]] (1829) – Assoc. Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court. Wrote dissent in the ''[[Dred Scott v. Sandford]]'' decision. Resigned from the Supreme Court as a matter of conscience over the decision.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mQ8UAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA87&lpg=PA87&dq=benjamin+curtis+porcellian+club&source=bl&ots=-MmyroHK1j&sig=actHFVq3nHEVC6bm5OLI89HjfUU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SlOoVK7nNouLoQT2poD4Cg&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=benjamin%20curtis%20porcellian%20club&f=false |title=Catalogue - Harvard University. Porcellian Club |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-02}}{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/supremecourt/personality/landmark_dred.html |title=The Supreme Court . Law, Power & Personality . Famous Dissents . Dred Scott v. Sandford (1857) |publisher=PBS.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-02}} *[[Richard Henry Dana, Jr.]] – Author, ''Two Years Before the Mast'' *[[Edward Everett]] – Secretary of State, President of Harvard, Congressman & Senator from Massachusetts, 15th Gov. of Massachusetts *[[Hamilton Fish III]] – College Football All-American and Congressman from New York (1910) *[[Miles Fisher]] – American film and television actor{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0279702/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 |publisher=IMDb.com|title=Miles Fisher|accessdate=2015-05-02}} *[[Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr.]] – author, poet, and professor at Harvard Medical School *Justice [[Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr.]] – Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, professor at Harvard Law School *[[William Henry Fitzhugh Lee]] (1858) – Son of [[Robert E. Lee]]. Great-grandson of [[George Washington]] through his mother's side (Custis family); Grandson of [[Henry Lee III|Richard Henry "Lighthorse" Lee]], Revolutionary War General. Resigned U.S. Army before outbreak of Civil War. Formed Virginia Raiders, later "Lee's Raiders". Later formed "Lee's Legion" by consolidating 8 companies of cavalry. Promoted Major General, [[Army of Northern Virginia]] (youngest in CSA). Extensive service with ANV through end of war. Surrendered with his father at [[Appomattox Court House National Historical Park|Appomattox]]."Crimson Confederates: Harvard Men who Fought for the South" by Helen P. Trimpi 2010 *[[Henry Cabot Lodge]] – American statesman, Congressman and Senator from Massachusetts. Senate Majority Leader. Noted historian. *[[James Russell Lowell]] – Poet{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,763262,00.html |title=Education: The Pore |publisher=TIME.com |date=1940-02-26 |accessdate=2015-05-02}} *[[Theodore Lyman]] (1858) – Union officer. Lt. Col. on Gen. Meade's staff. Cousin by marriage to Rob't. Gould Shaw. Congressman from Massachusetts. Overseer of Harvard Univ. 1st cousin to Charles W. Eliot, president of Harvard. *Maj. Gen. [[George Gordon Meade]] (1866) – Major General, United States Army. Commander of Union forces at Gettysburg. Hon. Member. *[[Paul Nitze]] – Presidential advisor, diplomat, foreign policy strategist, [[Secretary of the Navy]], [[United States Deputy Secretary of Defense|Deputy Secretary of Defense]], and co-founder of the [[School of Advanced International Studies]] (SAIS)Nicholas Thompson, "The Hawk and the Dove: Paul Nitze, George Kennan and the History of the Cold War", New York: Henry Holt and Company, 2009, {{ISBN|978-0805081428}} *[[Wendell Phillips]] – leading abolitionist *[[William Phillips (diplomat)|William Phillips]] – Diplomat, U.S. Ambassador to Italy *[[H. H. Richardson]] – Architect, designer of [[Trinity Church (Boston)|Trinity Church]] in Boston, Massachusetts, among others *President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] – 26th President of the United States *Brigadier General [[Theodore Roosevelt, Jr]] – Recipient of the Medal of Honor *[[Leverett Saltonstall]] – United States Senator from Massachusetts; 59th Governor of Massachusetts *[[Louis Agassiz Shaw II]] – Boston socialite; depicted in [[Robert Lowell]]'s poem "Waking in the Blue" as "Bobbie, Porcellian '29, a replica of Louis XVI without the wig..."{{cite book | first = Alex | last = Beam | year = 2002 | title = Gracefully Insane: The Rise and Fall of America's Premier Mental Hospital|publisher = Public Affairs|isbn=1-891620-75-4}} p. 174: "After a stint on Bowditch Hall, where Robert Lowell immortalized [[Louis Agassiz Shaw II]] as 'Bobbie...'" Beam quotes two pages of "Walking in the Blue", apparently as an introduction to the book, just before Chapter I."How the mentally ill have been treated — and mistreated — in America", ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', May 15, 2002.LaFerla, Ruth (2002), "Where the Upper Crust Crumbled Politely"; ''The New York Times,'' (Review of Alex Beam's book, ''Gracefully Insane''). July 28, 2002 [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C00E3DE1F38F93BA15754C0A9649C8B63&sec=health&pagewanted=print] *[[Robert Gould Shaw]] (1856–59) – Colonel of 54th Massachusetts Regiment, first all-volunteer Black regiment in Union Army, Civil War Killed in action at Ft. Wagner, as depicted in the motion picture ''[[Glory (1989 film)|Glory]]''. Subject of the ''[[Robert Gould Shaw Memorial]]'' by [[Augustus Saint-Gaudens]] *Justice [[Joseph Story]] (1795) – Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, leading Federalist theorist. Son of Elisha Story, member of [[Sons of Liberty]] and participant in the [[Boston Tea Party]]. *[[Charles Sumner]] (1830, LLD 1834) – Politician. Congressman & Senator from Massachusetts. leading abolitionist. Nearly beaten to death in 1856 on the floor of the house by [[Preston Brooks]] (D-So. Carolina) following a speech on slavery and slave holders. *[[Benjamin Ogle Tayloe]] (1814) – American businessman, diplomat, and political activist in Washington, D.C. during the first half of the 19th century. Son of Col. [[John Tayloe III]] of [[The Octagon House]], grandson of [[John Tayloe II]] of [[Mount Airy, Richmond County, Virginia]] and [[Benjamin Ogle]] Harvard University. Porcellian Club, Cambridge Publishing, Millard, Metcalf & Co., 1828 *[[Edward Thornton Tayloe]] - [[United States|American]] [[Diplomat]] and planter. Son of Col. [[John Tayloe III]] of [[The Octagon House]], grandson of [[John Tayloe II]] of [[Mount Airy, Richmond County, Virginia]], and [[Benjamin Ogle]] of [[Ogle Hall]]. Personal secretary to [[Joel Roberts Poinsett]] first [[United States Ambassador to Mexico|United States Minister to Mexico]]. Was selected to be [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]] under [[William Henry Harrison]], but President Harrison died before he could be confirmed. Some historians argue Harrison was on his way to [[The Benjamin Ogle Tayloe House]] with this information when he caught pneumonia.Harvard University. Porcellian Club, Cambridge Publishing, Allen and Farnham, 1857 *[[Henry C. Wayne|Henry Constantine Wayne]] (1834) – Confederate officer. Left Harvard to graduate USMA (1838). Major General of GA Militia under Gen. Johnston during [[Sherman's March to the Sea]]. Led irregular unit to harass Sherman on march to Savannah. Wayne's account of the defense of the Oconee Bridge [Battle of Ball's Ferry] (leading cadets of the GA Mil. Inst.) was included by Sherman in the 2d Ed. of his ''Memoirs''(1885). Son of [[James Moore Wayne]], Associate Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court{{cite web|url=http://georgiainfo.galileo.usg.edu/topics/historical_markers/county/washington/the-defense-of-oconee-bridge |title=Historical Markers by County |publisher=Georgiainfo.galileo.usg.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-05-02}} *[[Richard Whitney (financier)|Richard Whitney]] (1911) – President of the [[New York Stock Exchange]] (1930–1935), convicted embezzler. *[[Cameron Winklevoss]] (2004) – Rower, brought lawsuit vs. [[Facebook]] with his twin brother and [[Divya Narendra]]; 2008 Beijing Olympic Crew{{cite news |last=Prince |first=Lauren |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/education/porcellian-club-harvard-s-oldest-warns-against-women-members-n555576 |title=Porcellian Club, Harvard's Oldest, Warns Against Women Members |work=[[NBC News]] |date=April 14, 2016 |accessdate=2016-11-25 }} *[[Tyler Winklevoss]] (2004) – American rower and twin brother of Cameron; 2008 Beijing Olympic Crew *[[Grenville Lindall Winthrop]] (1864-1943), American art collector.{{cite news|title=Unveiled: For the first time, a recluse's treasures go traveling. |first=Christopher|last=Reed |url=http://harvardmagazine.com/2003/03/unveiled.html |newspaper=[[Harvard Magazine]] |location=Cambridge, Massachusetts |date=March 2003 |accessdate = October 12, 2015 }} *[[Owen Wister]] (1882) – Author, ''The Virginian'' According to a 1940 ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' article:
The Pork had as members James Russell Lowell, the two famed Oliver Wendell Holmeses (the author of Autocrat of the Breakfast Table and the Supreme Court Justice), [[Owen Wister]], Senator [[Henry Cabot Lodge]], President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] (the [[Franklin Roosevelt]]s go [[Fly Club]]). Among its living members are Massachusetts' Governor Leverett Saltonstall, Congressman [[Hamilton Fish]], Yachtsman Harold Stirling Vanderbilt, Poloist Thomas Hitchcock Jr., U. S. Ambassador to Italy William Phillips, Journalist [[Joseph Alsop]], [[Richard Whitney (financier)|Richard Whitney]], now of [[Sing Sing]] Prison, of whom all good Porkies prefer not to speak. The Pork is very much a family affair. Upon its roster, generation after generation, appear the same proud Boston names—Adams, Ames, Amory, Cabot, Gushing, etc.
According to a note to the obituary of the Club Steward on Monday, April 1, 1929, in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine:
The Porcellian roster includes Theodore Roosevelt, Theodore Roosevelt Jr., Poet Oliver Wendell Holmes, Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, Nicholas Longworth, Poet James Russell Lowell, Richard Henry (Two Years Before the Mast) Dana, Novelist Owen Wister, John Jay Chapman. The club's favorite brew is a mixture of beer and gin.
==See also== *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Cambridge, Massachusetts]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{National Register of Historic Places in Massachusetts}} [[Category:Collegiate secret societies]] [[Category:Student societies in the United States]] [[Category:Harvard University]] [[Category:Clubhouses on the National Register of Historic Places in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in the United States]] [[Category:1791 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Cambridge, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Harvard Square]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Cambridge, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Student organizations established in the 18th century]] [[Category:Historic district contributing properties in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Secret societies ]]

A '''publisher's reader''' or '''first reader''' is a person paid by a [[publisher]] or [[book sales club|book club]] to read [[manuscripts]] from the [[slush pile]], and to advise their employers as to quality and marketability of the work. In the US, most publishers use a full-time employee for this, if they do it at all. That employee is called an editorial assistant.
Most publishers in the US prefer to receive some type of shorter query, decide if the subject and author fit their current plans, and then request a copy of the manuscript. When a writer ignores this request or guideline, and sends a full manuscript, many publishers return them unopened. These publishers, then, wouldn't have anyone "reading slush."
The first person to read the submissions can exercise considerable influence over the offerings of the publishers for whom they work, and many unknown writers owed their first sale to a sympathetic publishers' reader or editorial assistant. A '''film reader''' performs a similar task by reading screenplays and advising producers and directors of their viability as a potential critical and commercial success.
==External links== * [http://en.wikisource.org/w/index.php?title=User:Tim_Starling/ScanSet_PNG_demo&vol=22&page=ED2A645 1911 ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' on publishing] * Jeanne Rosenmayer Fahnestock, "Geraldine Jewsbury: The Power of the Publisher's Reader," ''Nineteenth-Century Fiction'', Vol. 28, No. 3 (Dec., 1973), pp. 253-272. * Nash, Andrew, "A Publisher's Reader on the Verge of Modernity: The Case of Frank Swinnerton," ''Book History'', Vol. 6, 2003, pp. 175–195.

{{distinguish|Science communication|Scientific writing|Scholarly communication}} '''Scientific communication''' is a part of [[information science]] and the [[sociology of science]] which study researchers' use of formal and informal information channels, their communicative roles (e.g., "gatekeepers"), the utilization of the formal publication system and similar issues.
==Literature== *Björk, B.C. (2005). A lifecycle model of the scientific communication process. LEARNED PUBLISHING, 18(3), 165-176. *Fjordback Søndergaard, Trine; Andersen, Jack & Hjørland, Birger (2003). Documents and the communication of scientific and scholarly information. Revising and updating the UNISIST model. Journal of Documentation, 59(3), 278-320. (Available at: https://web.archive.org/web/20050320083023/http://www.db.dk/bh/UNISIST.pdf) *Hurd, J. M. (2000). The transformation of scientific communication: A model for 2020. Journal of the American Society for Information Science, 51(14), 1279-1283. *Kling, R. & McKim, G. (2000). Not just a matter of time: Field differences and the shaping of electronic media in supporting scientific communication. JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY FOR INFORMATION SCIENCE, 51(14), 1306-1320. *Nelson, C. E. & Pollock, D. K. (Eds.). (1970). Communication Among Scientists and Engineers. Lexington, Massachusetts: Health Lexington Books. *Meadows, A. J. (1974). Communication in Science. London: Butterworths. *Meadows, A. J. (1998). Communicating Research. San Diego, CA: Academic Press. *Mogull, S. A. (2017). ''Scientific and Medical Communication: A Guide for Effective Practice''. New York: Routledge. Available at: https://www.routledge.com/Scientific-And-Medical-Communication-A-Guide-For-Effective-Practice/Mogull/p/book/9781138842557 *Vickery, B. (2000). Scientific Communication in History. Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press. *Wojick, D. E.; Warnick, W. L.; Carroll, B. C. & Crowe, J. (2006). The Digital Road to Scientific Knowledge Diffusion. A Faster, Better Way to Scientific Progress? Commentary. D-Lib Magazine, 12(6). Available at: http://www.dlib.org/dlib/june06/wojick/06wojick.html
[[Category:Information science]] [[Category:Science studies]] [[Category:Communication]]

[[File:Kauno_senamiestis_2009-07-18.jpg|thumb|300px|Former building of the printing press Šviesa]] The '''Society of Saint Casimir''' ({{lang-lt|Šv. Kazimiero draugija}}) was a Lithuanian society that published [[Lithuanian-language]] books and periodicals, many on Roman Catholic church and faith. Established in 1905, right after the [[Lithuanian press ban]] was lifted, the society published a total of about 740 books and several periodicals, including the first full Roman Catholic [[Bible translation into Lithuanian]] in six volumes in 1911–1937. From 1918 it operated its own printing press Šviesa. The society was liquidated after [[Soviet occupation of Lithuania (1940)|Lithuania was occupied]] by the [[Soviet Union]] in June 1940.
==Secret student society== The society can trace its roots to 1888 when [[Juozas Tumas-Vaižgantas]] organized a secret student society, known as the Lovers of Lithuania Society (''Lietuvos mylėtojų draugija''), at the [[Kaunas Priest Seminary]].<ref name=bz109>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|p=109}}</ref> At that time Lithuania was part of the [[Russian Empire]] and [[Lithuanian press ban|Lithuanian-language books we banned]] by the Tsarist authorities. The society had a written program which emphasized service the church and Lithuania, use of the Lithuanian language, publication of Lithuanian religious literature, and development of Lithuanian patriotism. Leaving written evidence was dangerous as its activities were illegal and the members could easily be arrested by the Tsarist police.<ref name=bz109/> Therefore, the society split – Tumas-Vaižgantas and nine others established a less formal society. It became known as the Society of Saint Casimir when one of its members, Paulius Šilinskas, obtained relics of [[Saint Casimir]], patron saint of Lithuania.<ref>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|pp=109–110}}</ref> The society translated into Lithuanian and published several books, including a work by Irish Cardinal [[Nicholas Wiseman]],<ref>{{harvnb|Giedrienė|2013}}</ref> collection of [[Gospel (liturgy)|gospels]] published by [[Józef Zawadzki (publisher)|Józef Zawadzki]] in 1857, catechism by Roch Filochowski.<ref name=bz110>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|p=110}}</ref> At its peak as many as a third of the seminary students were its members, but the society was short-lived.<ref>{{harvnb|Laukaitytė|1991|p=93}}</ref>
==Establishment== The [[Lithuanian press ban]] was lifted in 1904 and Lithuanian clergy returned to the idea of publishing religious literature in the Lithuanian language. In July 1905, about 40 priests gathered in [[Plungė]] to celebrate construction of a new church. They established a publishing company Šaltinis (stream, source), chaired by Vincentas Jarulaitis. Bishop of Samogitia {{illm|Mečislovas Leonardas Paliulionis|lt}} approved the initiative but was dissatisfied that the organization was not based in [[Kaunas]].<ref>{{harvnb|Laukaitytė|1991|p=94}}</ref> Therefore, he called a meeting of about 20 members of the clergy from three dioceses ([[Diocese of Samogitia]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Vilnius|Diocese of Vilnius]], and [[Diocese of Sejny]]) in October 1905. The priests included {{illm|Povilas Januševičius|lt}}, [[Juozas Tumas-Vaižgantas]], [[Vladas Mironas]], [[Alfonsas Petrulis]].<ref>{{harvnb|Laukaitytė|1991|pp=94–95}}</ref> The meeting decided to establish a publishing company on 13 October 1905 in Kaunas. Its initial capital was set at 1,800 [[Russian ruble|rubles]] and 1,200 rubles were transferred from Šaltinis.<ref name=lau95/>
Its new chairman, {{illm|Adomas Dambrauskas-Jakštas|lt}}, reorganized the company into a society which was officially registered on {{OldStyleDate|16 October|1906|3 October}}. During its first official meeting on 30 November, the society registered 178 members.<ref name=sto/><ref name=bz111>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|p=111}}</ref> With the help of Bishop Paliulionis and Cardinal [[Serafino Cretoni]], the society obtained an [[indulgence]] from [[Pope Pius X]] on 10 April 1907. Its members were granted full indulgence on joining the society, on the feast day of Saint Casimir, on four other feasts (i.e. [[Feast of the Immaculate Conception]], [[Candlemas]], [[Nativity of Saint John the Baptist]], and [[Nativity of Mary]]), and on the deathbed.<ref>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|pp=116–117}}</ref> A partial indulgence for seven years and seven quadragenes was granted as well for praying on certain feasts.<ref>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|p=117}}</ref>
==Activities== In the context of the [[Russian Revolution of 1905]], the society harbored political aspirations. After the [[Great Seimas of Vilnius]], the priests wanted to establish the [[Lithuanian Christian Democratic Party]] and, with the help of the society, publish ''Žiburys'' (light, beacon) magazine. However, these plans were opposed by Bishop Paliulionis and new chairman Dambrauskas-Jakštas did not adopt a political agenda.<ref>{{harvnb|Laukaitytė|1991|pp=95–96}}</ref>
The society started off by publishing small and cheap booklets, mostly translations. The first 13-page booklet on good confession was published in 50,000 copies and cost three kopeykas.<ref name=bz111/><ref>{{harvnb|Tapinas|1997|p=497}}</ref> Before 1918, the society published 231 numbered and four not numbered books.<ref>{{harvnb|Vinco Kudirkos biblioteka|2016}}</ref> During its existence, the society published about 740 books. About a quarter of these were works of fictions. Lithuanian authors included [[Maironis]], [[Vaižgantas]], [[Lazdynų Pelėda]]. Other books were published on religious, scientific, popular topics.<ref name=bz113>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|p=113}}</ref> The society published the first full Roman Catholic [[Bible translation into Lithuanian]] in six volumes in 1911–1937. The translation was prepared by Archbishop [[Juozapas Skvireckas]] from the [[Vulgate]].<ref>{{harvnb|Baršys|2015|p=15}}</ref> The society also published a textbook on the [[history of Lithuania]] by {{illm|Antanas Alekna|lt}} which was republished nine times in 1909–1934 and was the most widely used history textbook in interwar Lithuania.<ref name=sto/><ref>{{harvnb|Ivinskis|1936|pp=417–418}}</ref> Alekna also wrote and the society published a book on the history of the church (three editions in 1919–1929) and a monograph on Bishop [[Motiejus Valančius]] (1922).<ref name=sto/> It also published periodicals ''Nedėldienio skaitymai'', ''[[Ateitis]]'', ''Garnys'', ''Vienybė'', ''Žvaigždė'', ''Ganytojas'', ''Žemdirbys'', ''Draugija'', ''[[Rygos garsas]]''.<ref name=sto/><ref name=bz113/>
The society also organized local chapters to distribute the publications and educate local residents on Catholic values and worldview. The chapters were also active in fighting illiteracy, smoking and alcohol consumption, organizing reputable entertainment (e.g. musical performances or sport competitions).<ref>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|pp=117–118}}</ref> By 1914, the society had some 10,000 members.<ref name=sto>{{harvnb|Stonienė|2006}}</ref> The membership peaked at about 15,000 members, of which 56% were abroad – mostly in United States but also in Italy, Poland, Palestine, Latvia.<ref name=bz113/> By 1939, the membership dipped to 5,000 with about 1,000 members in United States.<ref name=sto/>
In 1912, the society purchased premises near the [[Town Hall, Kaunas|Town Hall]] and the [[Kaunas Priest Seminary]] (present-day Rotušės a. 23).<ref name=bz112>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|p=112}}</ref> Most of its publications were published at the printing press of [[Saliamonas Banaitis]] which was located at the same building. The society purchased this press in 1918 and renamed it Šviesa (light). The society established a book shop at its headquarters in 1913. Later, smaller book shops were opened in [[Vilnius]] (1918), [[Šiauliai]] (1919), [[Telšiai]], [[Ukmergė]] (1921), [[Tauragė]], [[Radviliškis]] (1922), [[Panevėžys]], [[Mažeikiai]] (1923), [[Laisvės alėja]], Kaunas (1925), [[Vilkaviškis]] (1931), and [[Plungė]] (1932).<ref name=bz112/> It also had a candle workshop which produces candles for churches and distributed goods of foreign manufacturers such as microscopes by [[Ernst Leitz GmbH]], typewriters by the [[Underwood Typewriter Company]], radios by [[Radio H. Mende GmbH]].<ref name=bz114/>
==Liquidation== The society was liquidated soon after [[Soviet occupation of Lithuania (1940)|Lithuania was occupied]] by the [[Soviet Union]] in June 1940. On 12 July, its chairman Mykolas Vaitkus was dismissed by the deputy Minister of the Interior of the [[People's Government of Lithuania]]. On 31 August, its name was changed to Raudonoji vėliava (Red Flag).<ref name=bz114>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|p=114}}</ref> The society was closed on 15 October 1940 by an order of the [[Council of Ministers of the Lithuanian SSR|Council of People's Commissars]] of the [[Lithuanian SSR]]. Society's property was nationalized and unsold books were burned or recycled.<ref name=bz115>{{harvnb|Bloznelis|Zimnachaitė|2008|p=115}}</ref>
==Chairmen== Chairmen of the Society of Saint Casimir were: * Vincentas Jarulaitis (1905–1906)<ref name=lau95>{{harvnb|Laukaitytė|1991|p=95}}</ref> * {{illm|Adomas Dambrauskas-Jakštas|lt}} (1906–1938)<ref name=bz111/> * {{illm|Mykolas Vaitkus|lt}} (1938–1940)<ref name=bz114/> * Albertas Kleinas (acting, July–October 1940)<ref name=bz114/>
==References== ;In-line {{reflist|30em}}

Kazimiero draugijos kelias |url=https://eltalpykla.vdu.lt/bitstream/handle/1/31799/ISSN2335-8734_2008_N_9.PG_107-119.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y |journal=Kauno istorijos metraštis |year=2008 |volume=9 |language=lt |issn=2335-8734 |ref=harv}} *{{cite web| first=Rima |last=Giedrienė |year=2013 |url=http://www.radviliskiobiblioteka.lt/lt/krastotyra/krastieciai/114-p-nauja/434-pranckietis-kazimieras |title=Pranckietis (Pronckietis) Kazimieras |work=Kraštiečiai |publisher=Radviliškio rajono savivaldybės viešoji biblioteka |ref=harv |language=lt |accessdate=17 December 2017}} *{{cite journal |first=Zenonas |last=Ivinskis |title=Antanas Alekna 1872—1930 |url=http://www.prodeoetpatria.lt/files/pdf-straipsniai/Suv-darbai-II/ZENONAS%20IVINSKIS%20-%20Antanas%20Alekna.pdf |journal=Suvažiavimo darbai |date=1936 |volume=II |publisher=Lietuvių katalikų mokslo akademija |language=lt |issn=1392-0499 |ref=harv}} *{{cite journal |first=Regina |last=Laukaitytė |year=1991 |title=Dėl Šv. Kazimiero draugija |encyclopedia=[[Visuotinė lietuvių enciklopedija]] |publisher=Mokslo ir enciklopedijų leidybos centras |language=lt |ref=harv}} *{{cite encyclopedia| encyclopedia=Žurnalistikos enciklopedija |url=http://www.kf.vu.lt/dokumentai/publikacijos/Zurnalistikos-enciklopedija.pdf |editor-first=Laimonas |editor-last=Tapinas |title="Šviesa" |language=lt |location=Vilnius |publisher=Pradai |year=1997 |isbn=9986-776-62-7 |display-editors=etal |ref=harv}} *{{cite web |date=2016-01-26 |title=Šv. {{Infobox ethnic group| | group = White people in Botswana | image = | caption = | population = ~63,834 | popplace= [[Gaborone]], [[Francistown]], [[Ghanzi]], [[Serowe]], [[Lobatse]] | langs = [[English language|English]], [[Afrikaans]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Serbian language|Serbian]] | rels = [[Christianity]], [[Judaism]] | related = [[White people in Zambia]], [[White people in Zimbabwe]], [[White South African]]s }}
'''White people in Botswana''' are [[Demographics of Botswana|Botswana]] people whose ancestry lies within the continent of [[Europe]], most notably the [[United Kingdom]] and the [[Netherlands]].
Currently, White Africans are a minority ethnic group in Botswana, accounting for a little more than 3% of the country's population.<ref name=cia>{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bc.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook -- Botswana |accessdate=2013-09-26 |publisher=CIA | archiveurl= https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bc.html| archivedate= 22 August 2013 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The White population usually speak [[Afrikaans]] as well as other European languages, most notably [[English language|English]].
==History== [[White Africans|European]] people began to immigrate into what is today the nation of Botswana in the 19th century, starting with the [[Afrikaner|Boer]] people. The [[Dorsland Trek]] in the late 19th and early 20th centuries saw thousands of Boer families migrate from [[South Africa]] to present-day [[Namibia]] by way of Botswana. Many families stayed, especially in [[Ghanzi]], which is in the [[Kalahari Desert]]. White Tswana people come from a variety of backgrounds, including families of British, Boer, [[German people|German]], and [[Greek people|Greek]] descent.
Additionally, there is a fairly significant [[Serbian people|Serbian]] community in the country, mainly families of immigrants from [[Yugoslavia]] who came beginning in the 1950s. There is a Serbian Society in Gaborone, which regularly hosts a variety of cultural events. In 2016 construction began on the first [[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian Orthodox]] church in Botswana, the St. Nicholas Church.<ref>“Corner-Stone for the First Orthodox Church in Botswana.” Regular Session of the Holy Assembly of Bishops of the Serbian Orthodox Church Begins | Serbian Orthodox Church [Official Web Site], Serbian Orthodox Church, 25 Nov. 2016, www.spc.rs/eng/cornerstone_first_orthodox_church_botswana.In-text Citation</ref>
==Notable people== *[[Hendrik van Zyl]], famed trader and politician in [[Ghanzi]] *[[Christian de Graaff]], MP, Minister of Agriculture *[[Roy Blackbeard]], MP, High Commissioner from Botswana to the [[United Kingdom]] *[[Derek Jones (mayor)|Derek Jones]], Mayor of [[Gaborone]] *[[Ruth Williams Khama]], [[First Lady of Botswana]] *[[Samantha Paxinos]], Olympic swimmer for Botswana *[[Benjamin Steinberg]], MP, first Treasurer of the [[Botswana Democratic Party]]
==See also== {{Portal|Botswana}} *[[White Africans]] *[[White South Africans]] *[[White Namibians]] *[[Afrikaners]]
== References and footnotes == {{Reflist}} *[http://www.serbiansocietybotswana.org/who-we-are Serbian Society of Botswana]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2018}} {{Expert subject|India|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = Zeliangrong people |population = 500,000 |languages = [[Zeliangrong language]] |religions = Christianity |related = Other [[Naga tribes]] }}
'''Zeliangrong''' people are one of the major indigenous Naga communities living in the tri-junction of [[Assam]], [[Manipur]] and [[Nagaland]] in India. The term "Zeliangrong" refers to the [[Zeme Naga|Zeme]], [[Liangmei Naga|Liangmai]] and [[Rongmei Naga|Rongmei]] Naga tribes combined together.<ref>{{cite book | title = Women of Manipur | author = G. K. Ghosh, Shukla Ghosh | edition = illustrated | publisher = APH | year = 1997 | isbn = 978-81-7024-897-2 | page = 4 }}</ref> Earlier, the term also covered the [[Inpui]] tribe.<ref>Richard Kamei, Manash Firaq Bhattacharjee and Pradip Phanjoubam. [https://thewire.in/166021/letters-tribalism-without-tribes/ Tribalism Without the Tribes]. 8 August 2017.</ref> The proper noun Zeliangrong does not denote a tribe but, rather, a union of tribes or, rather, the apex tribe of three aforementioned tribes (Zeme Naga, Liangmai Naga, Rongmei Naga).
The descendants of Hoi of Makuilongdi (Makhel) were divided and were made peripheral appendages to three political entities - Manipur, Naga Hills (Nagaland) and the North Cachar District of Assam.
The Zeliangrongs number around four hundred and fifty thousand according to the 2011 census, though their population may actually number around five hundred thousand in the three states of Assam, Manipur and Nagaland. The Zeliangrong may be classified as an ethno-cultural entity. The Zeliangrong belong to the larger [[Southern Mongoloid]] population and their language belongs to the [[Tibeto-Burman]] family of languages.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ashthefoodie.wordpress.com/2010/03/29/salt-of-the-soil-the-zeliangrong-story/|title=‘Salt’ of the Soil-The Zeliangrong Story|date=2010-03-29|work=FOOD FOR THOUGHT|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
The Zeliangrong have been living in the present location of their land since time immemorial, in a compact and contiguous geographical setting of approximately 12,000 km<sup>2</sup> lying between 93 degrees E and 94 degree E longitude and 94.40 degrees and 24 degrees N latitude in N. C Hills of Assam; Peren district of Nagaland; Tamenglong district, Sardar hills of Senapati district, northern part Henglep subdivision of Churachanpur district, Jiribam subdivision of Imphal district, Imphal valley and Silchar Town along with various villages such as [[Binnakandi]], [[Lakhipur]], and its adjoining slopes in Manipur.
==Etymology== The ethnonym ‘Zeliangrong’ is traced back to the three kindred brothers. The three brothers are the ''Zeme'' (dwellers of the warmer) or ''Mejahme'' (lower region), ''Liangmai'' (men of the North) the original Northerner; on the other hand the term ''Rongmei'' (people settled in the south) and finally Inpui (Puimei). The word ''Zeliangrong'' was first coined on 15 February 1947 at Keishamthong Imphal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://e-pao.net/epSubPageExtractor.asp?src=news_section.opinions.Opinion_on_Manipur_Integrity_Issue.Bill_108_of_2011_and_need_to_understand_the_words_Naga_Zeliangrong_and_balkanization|title=Bill 108 of 2011 and need to understand the words Naga Zeliangrong and balkanization|website=e-pao.net|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> The terminology Zeliangrong was coined in coherence with the solidarity movement after [[Partition of India|India’s independence]]. The [[Zeme people|Zeme]], [[Liangmei]] and [[Rongmei]] dominates the demography in the districts of [[Peren]] in Nagaland, [[Tamenglong]] in Manipur, [[Haflong]] and other parts of [[North Cachar Hills]] in Assam. Not to forget the parts of the [[Barak Valley]], [[Kohima]] the capital of Nagaland, [[Dimapur]] the commercial hub of Nagaland, [[Loktak]], [[Bishnupur, Manipur|Bishnupur]] also [[Imphal]] the capital of Manipur comes under the fold of Zeliangrong people.<ref>{{Citation|title=A brief account of the Zeliangrong People|url=http://www.zeliangrong.com/zeliangrong/zeliangrong-history|work=Zeliangrong Identity|publisher=Makaam Foundation|accessdate=23 August 2011}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Zeme Naga]] * [[Liangmai Naga]] * [[Rongmei Naga]] * [[Heraka]]

==External links== * [http://nambon.com/history/zeliangrong Zeliangrong History (The Exodus)] * [http://nambon.com/zeliangrong-region Introduction to Zeliangrong Nagas] * [http://www.zeliangrong.com/zeliangrong/zeliangrong-history A brief account of the Zeliangrong People]
